results.headline: Review: An Anti-Semite Learns of His Jewish Roots in ‘Keep Quiet’
results.summary_short: This documents how the career of the far-right Hungarian politician Csanad Szegedi was upended when he found out about his lineage.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Keep Quiet

results.headline: Review: Saving Dad, and Finding Herself, in ‘My Name Is Emily’
results.summary_short: Evanna Lynch, of “Harry Potter,” plays a teenager who leaves her foster home to search for her institutionalized father.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Name Is Emily

results.headline: Review: In ‘You’re Killing Me Susana,’ Fidelity Is Up for Debate
results.summary_short: Gael García Bernal plays a man pursuing his wife, who seems to have left him.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of You’re Killing Me Susana

results.headline: Review: ‘Everybody Loves Somebody,’ a Rom-Com With Bite
results.summary_short: A messed-up heroine is asked to choose between naughty and nice in Catalina Aguilar Mastretta’s sophomore feature, which is predictable but satisfying.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Everybody Loves Somebody

results.headline: Review: Matt Damon Battles Clusters of Monsters in ‘The Great Wall’
results.summary_short: Zhang Yimou’s costume spectacle offers drooling creatures, glowering warriors, a swaggering mercenary and a message about China’s might.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Great Wall

results.headline: Review: ‘A Cure for Wellness’ Is a Riot of Film References. With Eels.
results.summary_short: This thriller from Gore Verbinski makes for a nice game of Name That Movie Influence as it treads the boundary between homage and outright plagiarism.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Cure for Wellness

results.headline: Review: Cute Cats of ‘Kedi,’ Rekindling a ‘Love of Life’
results.summary_short: This documentary profiles distinctive street cats in Istanbul and the human communities that interact with them.

results.headline: Review: ‘A United Kingdom’ With Love That Tested Racial Tolerance
results.summary_short: This romance illustrates the struggle for African independence from colonialism, under the shadow of apartheid.

results.headline: Review: ‘Sex Doll,’ a High-End Prostitute With a Persistent Follower
results.summary_short: Sylvie Verheyde’s film peels away layers of possibility until it becomes clear that there is almost nothing underneath.

results.headline: Review: ‘I Am Jane Doe’ Takes Aim at Escort Ads
results.summary_short: This documentary is a chronicle of the fight to hold an online classifieds site liable for children being sold into sex slavery.

results.headline: Review: ‘Land of Mine,’ an Oscar Nominee, Explores Postwar Perils and Ethics
results.summary_short: The tension between justice and vengeance is the subject of Martin Zandvliet’s tight and suspenseful feature, which is up for best foreign language film.

results.headline: Review: ‘Don’t Hang Up’ Has a Menace on the Line
results.summary_short: This formulaic horror movie features teenagers behaving badly and suffering the consequences.

results.headline: Review: Juggling ‘Stray Bullets’ and Homework
results.summary_short: This film with crooks and a hit man is typical, except it was made by a director, Jack Fessenden, who was still in high school.

results.headline: Review: ‘Eagles of Death Metal’ Revisits the Paris Terror Attack
results.summary_short: Colin Hanks’s documentary follows the band that was playing at the Bataclan in Paris when terrorists struck in 2015.

results.headline: Review: ‘Fifty Shades Darker,’ and Only Half as Watchable

results.headline: Review: ‘The Island Funeral’ Goes on a Restless Road Trip
results.summary_short: This second feature by the Thai director Pimpaka Towira finds three young adults on an enigmatic journey.

results.headline: Review: ‘John Wick: Chapter 2,’ a Roman Holiday With Shots Not Sparks
results.summary_short: This sequel is an altogether more solemn affair than the original, weighed down by the philosophy that more is always more.

results.headline: Review: ‘Left on Purpose’ Follows a Man Who Plans to Kill Himself
results.summary_short: This documentary focuses on Mayer Vishner, a man who has decided to end his life, and finds the filmmaker in an uncomfortable position.

results.headline: Review: In ‘1 Night,’ a Hotel, 2 Couples, a Bad Prom and a Reckoning
results.summary_short: This debut feature by Minhal Baig has two high school students, a couple in their 30s and a dash of charm.

results.headline: Review: ‘Speed Sisters,’ Revving to Go in the West Bank
results.summary_short: This documentary centers on the challenges faced by five young women who make up the first female streetcar racing team in the Middle East.
